segments.text: And I did realize that I had come to regard the Vietnamese as maybe less than human.
Maybe not all the time, but at times.
And I didn't like that myself.
And so I think I felt some of the guilt for that.
And maybe that was too much guilt.
But I know it contributed to the way I felt going home about what I've been a part of.
Because I had seen myself as strictly in the medical nursing role.
And I felt that was necessary and commendable.
But also, people at home were very much aware of me live.
And I think I did get a question about that.
So I think people looked at me differently.
They looked at all of us.
They looked at the uniform, I think.
And saw that whole thing was different, less honorable than it had been.
And how did the people treat you?
Like, people at home?
Did they...
They were glad to have me home.
They were?
I had extended three months.
I spent 15 months over there, which was three months longer than the usual tour.
And that had hurt my folks, had worried them.
And my mother, well, she read my letters very carefully and deciphered my handwriting.
My handwriting didn't look real normal to her.
Then I was, something was wrong.
They were real relieved.
What about other veterans?
Was there a problem with being a woman?
the woman veteran with the men veterans?
At that time?

I'm not sure who I was around, at least in that first six months, that was a veteran, other than a friend that I'd had before going over and while I was over, and then we saw each other after I was back.
I think everything was fine with us.
We didn't have to talk about it.
He knew what I'd gone through.
He had walked through pre-op and recovery once during a mass cow situation.
And I think his esteem, I mean, I don't think he really recognized feelings of esteem toward me before that, but I think he did afterwards.
But others, I don't think I was around any others.
There were guys from my class in high school who went, but I didn't see any of them during that time.
Then when I went back into the Army, I stayed out.
I got back in December and went back on active duty in June, I think.
Went back to El Paso where I'd been before.
And there were still people there I knew.
One of them was this Jimmy, who had been over with the weapons project.
And this other friend.
I don't think there was any change in the...
I don't remember any outstanding, any remarkable, anything remarkable to say about it.
Okay.
And I know you were involved with, talk about the network of other females who were in Vietnam that you kept up with.
Yeah.
I must have continued writing.
I must have written to some of the girls I had known over there.
Because once I was living in San Francisco, and that was two years, probably two years after I was back, I got together with some of them for the first time.
And these, for the most part, were girls who lived in the same hooch.
It was the Red Cross girl across...
across the hall.
Her brother was an MIA, and she had gone over, had not been in the Red Cross, but had gone over, had joined, thinking that if she could get over there, she could find out something about him.
And the gal who lived next to me, and a couple of others, and those two
I've seen recently, you know, in the last, well, I've talked to by phone and one of them I've seen.
And I think, you know, we'll continue to see each other.
The one I've supported, well, and it's been both ways.
But when we first really made contact again, we lost touch for a couple of years.
And at that point, she was going through losing her father, who was very, very sick.
And then soon he died.
And there was some other things going on.
And there was a parallel there.
And I was able to help her in the healing process.
Because what I had gone through had been very recent.
She was going through something, you know, right now.
And then also there was, you know, the stuff in the past.
The same kinds of things that I had done in the past.
And I had started working through that.
And so, you know, there was some sharing.
I've always kept in touch with a girl that I was in college with who went into the Army Student Nurse Program the same time I did.
And we see each other every three or four years and write, talk on the phone.
I'd like to know more, you know, people with the same experiences here.
There are some in the
the Dallas area, but I'm not connected with anyone that I, you know, feel a real rapport to.
And there are times when, well, there's a lot of times, frankly.
I wish more people had been through what I have been through, who know what I know.
You know, I feel that's a heavy burden for me.
blessing that more people don't know, but still.
What were your views of the war before you went, and what were your views after you came home?
Before, I didn't like war, but I saw it as necessary in certain instances.
And I think I felt, like many people did, that communism had to be contained and so on and so forth.
For some time after I got back, I didn't think much about it at all.
I was real relieved when it was over.
And it was over in time for my husband not to have to go.
He was a doctor and would have gone.
except he was in training, and his training lasted longer than the war did.
And next I thought, about the time that was ending and he was finishing his training, we started our family, and I had a son, and if I thought of it at all, I thought, well, you know, that's over.
And it was like, that's over, and there won't be any others.

instance and when I started I think going started the healing process myself I realized how bad it was the cost of the war made much more of an impact than I had before what happened was I started the healing and the grieving over the boyfriend
over the relationships.
I was involved more than once, romantically, while I was there.
But either he went, he left, you know, rotated home, or I did.
And it was just over.
I mean, this was not something that could continue.
And I had gone over promising myself, because, you know, when you're 23, marriage is on your mind.
Mm-hmm.
Promising myself that I would not marry somebody I met over there.
I knew this was going to be an artificial time, and that, um, probably would not be a good time and place to be making, you know, a lifetime decision.
But still, you just don't turn off a relationship.
And yet I did.
Over and over.
Mm-hmm.
And, um,
this boyfriend who was killed.
I didn't go through his funeral.
When I got over there, I went to work right away.
One of the first nurses I talked to was someone a little younger than I whose boyfriend had just been killed while she was in country.
I don't think she was on duty, but he came through our emergency room.
And she was bearing up.
And we thought, well, you know, my loss wasn't as great as hers.
We weren't engaged.
You know, that was a silly judgment to make, but that's the way I operated.
And then I just, you know, got busy doing what I had to do.
Never broke down in front of patients.
And then at home, you know, after I get off duty, instead of breaking down, I go to the officer's club and drink and dance.
I mean, I didn't sit there and, you know, just drink.
We danced and we flirted and we

carried on I mean we just played and played hard but the energy and the emotion you know was spent counter to the way it should have been so when I started working through all this I started working through the grief of it and cried like it had just happened
And then realized, you know, the whole thing was just so wasteful.
It was for nothing.
And by then it was being talked about as nothing, or had been for some time.
And was, you know, very angry.
Angry at our government.
Very distrustful of our government.
I mean, I don't trust anything the government says.
I really don't.
I don't trust anything I read in the newspaper.
I look at it and I wonder what really happened.
The beginning of this greeting began with a conversion experience coupled with the baptism of the Spirit.
Something Catholics don't expect to have happen.

just haven't grown up in that you know but that tradition hadn't haven't been part of a charismatic group whatever so it was very surprising when it happened and it happened as a healing really a healing gift over something that had happened in our parish and what had happened there there were some sudden losses i mean there was a big big uh
turn around in one of the ministries and people were gone and something was no longer there that had been there for me.
Something without warning.
And it was upsetting me terribly.
And then this happened and it was all alright.
And then a couple months later something happened which caused me to flash back to start remembering Vietnam.
And I realized what happened was that healing was just the beginning.
of a healing process that I would go through.
This thing at church, it mirrored what had happened before.
The sudden losses, the losses with no explanation, no chance to say goodbye.
And so it's feelings that come out that trigger these flashbacks.
And for me, the flashbacks were...
not violent, I had not been through anything that was violent to my person at least, but I just started remembering.
I remembered, you know, some of those stories I told you about pre-op and recovery.
I hadn't thought about those in years.
Some of the stuff I hadn't remembered at all.
You know, things just started coming back.
And with all of that, with
you know, with this conversion too, you know, seeing things differently, seeing things through the eyes of Christ as we should, then you look at war entirely differently.
You know, I'm very opposed now to that.
There was nothing just about what we were involved in.
There was nothing just about
We haven't had a just war in an awfully long time.
Don't talk just war to me.
I've gotten active in the peace movement, peace and justice issues.
I just see things entirely different.
You know, I look at what we're doing in Central America, in many places, but Central America especially, you know, it's just totally wrong.
It's just a continuation of all of them.
It's just, you know, people in power, I mean, they change.
Maybe they win.
It's good people, but they're...
It corrupts.
And then you get a bureaucracy the size of ours running away.
I don't know how people can stop it.
Did you join Vietnam Vets Against the War?
Not that group.
And how have your experiences in Vietnam affected your life?
Like what you do today?
What I'm doing today?
Like
How do they affect what you do now?
Well, I think that's why I do peace work.
Things have to change.
And those who have been a part of something like this have to speak out.
This business of the boy on the striker frame that I said reminded me of Jesus on the cross.
The purpose of the cross is so that we will go into resurrection.
It has no meaning if we don't go into resurrection.
And we don't have to find it out for ourselves like Jesus did.
He had no idea what was going to happen.
He was just plodding along, doing what he thought he was supposed to do.
and not really knowing why.
That man couldn't know what he was, you know, doing.
And it led him to a bad end.
But, you know, he was transformed.
He woke up with a big shock.
We don't have to do that.
We've got that model in front of us.
We know that these bad things can be turned around and be transformed.
And we have to do them because, you know, we're Christ on earth.
And so I believe that very strongly, and that's what I'm doing now.
I work...
I helped start a justice and peace committee, an education committee on justice and peace in our parish.
And I work with an ecumenical women's group, Church Women United.
They are involved in...
women and children's justice issues.
And this is international.
They're active at local, state, national, and international levels.
And that's exciting to me.
Women, I think, will make a difference.
Men are too hurt, too broken up themselves.
They haven't
I haven't seen what they've done in holding women down in this whole patriarchal tradition we've been a part of.
And women are coming out of that via the women's movement.
And it's a rough time.
There's a lot of animosity among women towards feminists.
But it's just something that has to be done.
Women are primary as caregivers.
Men can do this.
They can do it, and they do do it.
Some have done it very well.
But it is in us to do this, and this is the big caregiving.
We're the ones who, you know, heal the little fusses at home and keep a neighborhood going.
And so somehow we've got to make that part of the overall tradition that we live in.
I don't think women have to take over.
That wouldn't be any more right than men ruining the world.
It would be women ruining the world.
But it's all a healing process.
The wrongs, the hurts that have been done.
And as things are healed...
they blossom and they multiply and they're good and they're better than they were.
So I think that's what's come out of Vietnam.
And, you know, if you'd asked me all this seven years ago, I wouldn't have had any of this to say, I don't think.
The thing that woke me up and started all the Vietnam healing was the Beirut bombing.
What happened when someone was injured there, they might be picked up within minutes, certainly within a short time, within an hour usually.
It was very rare for somebody to be pinned down for a long time.
Usually they would pick up very soon in a hospital.
About three days later, the folks would find out about it.
His boyfriend was killed on the 3rd of September.
The family found out on the 6th.
His body got home on the 13th or 14th, 13th.
And when I saw the news clips about the Beirut bombing, it went through my mind.
They're not going to know who's killed for another three days or so.
Maybe three or four days before anyone knows.
And you know, right away, well, sometimes people don't know where their boys are stationed.
They don't know for sure if they're in a sensitive area.
But they often have an idea where the kids will write home and say, I think we're in.
But, you know, people will know.
that they've got somebody over there, and they'll be watching and wondering, you know, hoping against hope.
And it was just, you know, it was a short time, and they had six people, I think, identified from the Metroplex or this area as being in the area.
And then about the third day, they identified three guys who had been killed.
And I think it was a replay of that old tape,
for me.
I hadn't thought about that, you know, in so long as to, you know, how long it took, but I just knew.
You know, the first time I heard about that, I thought, you know, it's going to be three days.
And then it was during that week that all this stuff started coming back.
And another time, a couple years later, and I broke down.
I was just, I was a real mess.
A couple years later, it happened again.

And at that time, what upset me, I read a little thing, just a little clip in a Catholic newspaper saying that Coleco Industries planned to market a Rambo doll complete with weapons and accessories for
They didn't call it creative play, but something equally dumb and untrue.
And it was just like, bombs went off.
How can they do this?
How can they put something like that in the hands of children?
And before that, I had really, I think my son had one gun.
I just had not bought war toys for him.
Didn't identify him as war toys, just didn't buy these things.
And then, you know, I realized, I think that's when I realized that it wasn't over.
Things were going to, you know, continue to happen and my boy was at risk.
He was 12 at the time, you know, six years away from me.
So,
I suppose, you know, something could happen again that would trigger some, some memory, some reaction.
I think, I think if the men who were there weren't talking about it, um, I think they would, if they'd open themselves up to, uh, to healing, to reconciliation.
So many of the few guys I have talked to, they hold themselves accountable for things that they couldn't have been accountable for.
Those guys were young.
They were 18, 19, 20 years old.
In our culture, an 18 or 19-year-old is a baby.
He's not able to go out and support himself and a family.
You know, they're not making really adult decisions.
They were there, you know, strictly to kill or be killed.
And I had a medic tell me he had berated himself for years because he hadn't gone after a guy.
And he was pinned down.
He couldn't get out.
And by the time they got to him, the guy was dead.
There was this kid, 19 years old, who couldn't get to somebody because, you know, he would have been shot himself, bullets whizzing all around him.
And for years he carried that with him.
And it's so freeing when you let go of some, not just a hurt, but something you think you did wrong.
You know, call it a sin.
Or what you thought was sinful or
terrible mistake.
It's so freeing when you let go of that.
And I think we'd have a different country.
You know, you'd have more people fussing at the government for what they're doing in Central America.
We're paying for that now.
I am paying for that.
But it's got to be real, and people have to, you know, somehow it has to be real to them.
And those who were there and saw it, if they're not talking about it, they might not let it be real.
And there's a whole lot of others who, you know, who haven't seen it.
It can't be real unless we make it so.
And, you know, it doesn't take everybody thinking the same way, but it takes a certain population, a certain number in the population
When you get to a certain number, and the rest of the people will come around.
You just got a lot of followers, you know?
Anymore?
No, that's it.
Thank you.
